Murdoch meets with the family of murdered teen Milly Dowler, and personally apologizes for the hacking of Dowler's phone by News of the World staff.
Murdoch and his son, James, testify before Parliament's Culture, Media and Sport Committee on the phone hacking scandal enveloping News Group Intl.
During the testimony, a protester hits Murdoch with a pie made of shaving cream.
James Murdoch resigns as deputy COO, chairman and CEO of News International
John Ryley, the head of Sky News, admits to authorizing journalists to hack into emails of private citizens.
Sky News is owned by News Corp.
James Murdoch testifies before an independent British inquiry into journalistic ethics.
He insists that he knew little about the scale of phone hacking by people working for the News of the World.
Murdoch testifies before the same committee.
He admits to a cover-up of abuses at News of the World and apologizes for not paying more attention to the scandal.
British lawmakers investigating phone hacking at News of the World declare that Rupert Murdoch is not a "fit person to exercise the stewardship of a major international company."
News Corp. confirms that it plans to split into two publicly traded companies, one company for its television and film assets and the other for its newspaper and book publishing entities.
Once the split is completed, Rupert Murdoch will serve as chairman of both companies and will also serve as CEO of the media and entertainment company.
A News International spokesman says that Rupert Murdoch has stepped down from a number of company boards of directors, both in the UK and the US.
Murdoch tweets about "scumbag" celebrities.
Many speculated he was referring to singer Charlotte Church and television presenter
Jacqui Hames after they met with British Prime Minister David Cameron to discuss the potential reform of Britain's media laws.
Murdoch tweets later that he wasn't referring to "particular people" and apologizes for his language.
It is announced that Murdoch's sons will take control of 21st Century Fox on July 1.
Announces his engagement to Jerry Hall, the former model who has four children with Mick Jagger.
Marries Jerry Hall at Spencer House in London.
The celebratory wedding takes place at St. Bride's Church in London, the next day.
Takes over as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News Channel and Fox Business Network as Roger Ailes resigns amid allegations by Fox employees of sexual harassment.
Names Bill Shine and Jack Abernethy as co-presidents of Fox News to replace Ailes.
The two will report to Murdoch.
Murdoch's 21st Century Fox strikes a deal to take full control of Sky
The British government rules that Murdoch's 21st Century Fox should not be allowed to purchase Sky without a further investigation.
Fox says it will "continue to work constructively with the UK authorities."
21st Century Fox says it's pulling Fox off the air in Britain after failing to attract an audience.

UK culture secretary Karen Bradley says she intends to order an extensive review of 21st Century Fox's $15 billion planned takeover of Sky TV because of concerns over "genuine commitment to broadcasting standards" and the increased influence it would give the Murdoch family over British media.
The Walt Disney Company announces it is purchasing most of 21st Century Fox for $52.4 billion.
Forbes names Murdoch, with a net worth of $15 billion, No. 94 on its annual World's Billionaires list.
